text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review a
real-life actual review not Chokin
marilyn manson born villain this is the
latest LP from the band / songwriter /
singer frontman musician Brian Warner
and a lot of people may look at this
review and ask Anthony why do you even
bother you don't usually cover music
like this you are someone who has a huge
crush on on rock pop electronic
experimental metal and hip hop music for
the most part of the Independent
Business Assistance or suasion don't you
have some kind of natural hatred for
Marilyn Manson deep inside you that
cannot be shaken well the truth is back
in the day when I was a teenage fat non
music nerd guy who wouldn't know a punk
band if he heard one I thought Marilyn
Manson was awesome now what's his
influence on me and my enjoyment of his
music due to me being young and naive I
would say yes to an extent but I think
his music and his message had a lot of
merit to it from about the 90s up until
the year 2000 I think at the time when
he was at his hottest he was writing
some of the catchiest industrial and
alternative metal out there and even
though I wouldn't ever say one of his
albums topped the music of one of his
biggest and earlier supporters Trent
Reznor of Nine Inch Nails Marilyn
Manson's place in alternative metal and
industrial metal is not going anywhere
for a while because he definitely had
his own approach to this stuff sonically
and philosophically albums like
Antichrist Superstar were a nice mix of
just abrasive hard rock elements and
electronic music - most
time the selfie is extremely raw noisy
and just grim and if you could see
yourself getting past a Marilyn Manson
stigma I would definitely try checking
out this album because if you really
look into it it is a very well produced
and extremely textured album and is very
much powered by Marilyn Manson's
greatness as a front man he is just the
high priest of everything offensive on
this album from his really low gothy
kroons to his throat shredding screams
he is just a great singer on this LP
though the darkness on this album is
kind of melodramatic and it always has
been with Marilyn Manson the production
and the songwriting makes up for it in a
big way for me now the only thing that I
think could potentially overshadow
Marilyn Manson's music into the future
if it hasn't already is his image his
message because Antichrist Superstar was
not just an album it wasn't just music
it was a slap in the face of religion of
censorship of conformity you could boil
it down to shock rock but Marilyn Manson
definitely had contemporaries that were
trying to push buttons as well like
Mudvayne and Slipknot Rob Zombie - but
Marilyn Manson definitely proved to have
stronger tunes on his side thanks to the
collective writing abilities of him and
his band and you can argue that there
are plenty of artists out there who
pushed the boundaries further than he
did whether it be just visually and
aesthetically or just philosophically or
politically I would say a guy like GG
Allin definitely went a lot further than
Marilyn Manson did in terms of lyrical
content and stage antics - but Marilyn
Manson understood that there is a
balance here if you're going to affect a
widespread audience there's only so far
you can go before you just start
alienating people he just found this
pocket where he was able to throw
atheism and war and violence and
sexuality
drugs into the public consciousness with
this weird white-faced
lanky lipstick wearing image but was
still appealing and catchy enough from a
musical perspective to appeal to an
audience large enough to just keep his
message into the mainstream
now Antichrist Superstar which which
gained I think the most attention out of
all of his albums was easily the
freakshow in his discography his next LP
mechanical animals was somewhat of a
retreat still push buttons but was much
more of an introspective look themes of
conformity Fame drug addiction sonically
the album had more since was more
palatable catchy er a lot less noisy and
some people would even call it his glam
rock album it was an interesting
transformation and to me after this
album comes my favorite in Manson's
discography hollywood on this album
anthem goes back toward shoving all of
these taboos and everyone's faces but
with a bit more refinement definitely
not as harsh as Antichrist superstar but
in a lot of ways just as grim and
dealing in death Fame and again religion
but once we just cracked the barrier of
the new millennium I fell out of favor
with with Marilyn Manson personally for
a lot of reasons first off Marilyn
Manson's next album the Golden Age of
grotesque was so repetitive and filled
with so many bad and just fluffy
pointless hooks that even his most
hardcore fans had to recognize there's a
bit of a fall from grace going on here
not to mention it really lacked the
variation and the ambition of his
previous three albums it seemed like his
crusade to shock in his fight against
censorship was kind of dying actually I
would I would say it kind of succeeded
because people in general and even in
the mainstream media were just no longer
repulsed by Marilyn Manson's favorite
buttons to push
kind of wore off which
really took away Manson's
bread-and-butter maybe his his muse
the album's eat me drink me and the high
end of low definitely tried to fill
these gaps with tracks that that
described violent sex fantasies or maybe
some hoax that had more profanity in
them musically Marilyn Manson was
definitely revealing some some personal
music influences a track would pop up
and had a strong blues influence that
would be songs that had an even stronger
New Wave influence maybe even an
old-school post-punk influence to them
Plus around this time I had just gotten
into punk music and had decided that it
was just nothing else in the world worth
listening to instead and I don't think
that it's any coincidence that Marilyn
Manson's fallen popularity correlates
directly with most of his core audience
graduating from high school and going on
to college but born villain Marilyn
Manson's new record and his first since
being let out of his contractual
obligations with longtime label partner
Interscope Records is not really sitting
all that well with me and the biggest
and most obvious reason right off the
bat is that with Interscope Records
leaving
so did Marilyn Manson's production
budget it's not an unlistenable album
but Marilyn Manson has not been sounding
this raw since portrait of an American
family he continues on this LP to kind
of show his love for very early goth
rock and post-punk it most definitely
shows up on the track the gardener which
has this this dance beat this groovin
bass line as well some shots of guitar
noise and Marilyn Manson doing this very
kind of cocky spoken word piece I
actually think it's pretty great and the
song murderers are getting be every day
has a very harsh ministry style
industrial metal quality to it that is
just very abrasive however there are
moments where the stripped back
recording quality does not do this album
any favors whatsoever like on the song
pistol-whipped you hear fingers sloppily
rubbing against the guitar strings as
they
go up and down for riffs and the song no
reflection I'm surprised it's a single
off of this album because it is just so
badly edited and produced it just feels
like a really nasty demo and there's not
much subtlety or detail or variety on
this album outside of a few slower
ballads toward the end that may feature
keyboard or acoustic guitar
I mean Marilyn Manson has really really
reverted back to a simple structure of
just drums vocals and guitars and that
would be fine if I felt these tracks for
the most part had that energy and had
that Drive of early Marilyn Manson but
it doesn't so it just ends up making
these very simply built songs that last
four to five minutes each dragged on
especially the song slow motion Manson's
usual melodrama and his trademark kroons
are on here but I'm just in no mood to
deal with it with all this weakened
production and undercooked songwriting
there are moments on here where I think
a track will emulate his older style and
it will feel pretty good like hey cruel
world
badass riffs and Manson doing this
insane vibrato on his vocal and that is
one of the things that I would say
actually advances and becomes
interesting on this album Manson's voice
he's still a great screamer and still a
great crooner but he's also
experimenting with doing some shrieking
doing some whispered vocals singing in
different registers more vibrato
spoken-word like I said - he still got
personality but this record just does
not feel all that pleasing I like some
of the post-punk vibes coming off this
album but it feels like the further we
get away from the 90s and and the
further we get away from Manson's
relevancy as a crusader against
censorship just the more off the mark
his music kind of feels I think
eventually like Arthur Brown or like
Alice Cooper Marilyn Manson will go down
in history as one of the greatest shock
rockers to ever dominate a decade but
still if he keeps putting out albums
like this
I think what I mentioned earlier will
most definitely happen and his image
will just drown out his musical
contributions kind of feeling a strong
three to a light four on this album but
what did you guys think of it if in fact
you listened to it it was - it was
Anthony Fantana Marilyn Manson born
villain forever
